unnormalised: **Rental Agreements: Your Friendly Neighborhood Guide (Because Nobody Wants a Landlord Drama!)**
normalised: Rental Agreements: Your Friendly Neighborhood Guide (Because Nobody Wants a Landlord Drama!)

unnormalised: So, you're about to rent out your cool apartment in Bandra, or maybe you're a student looking for a PG near IIT Delhi? Either way, let's talk rental agreements. Seriously, don't skip this! It’s like the recipe for a killer biryani – if you miss an ingredient, things get messy.
normalised: So, you're about to rent out your cool apartment in Bandra, or maybe you're a student looking for a P G near I I T Delhi? Either way, let's talk rental agreements. Seriously, don't skip this! It’s like the recipe for a killer biryani – if you miss an ingredient, things get messy.

unnormalised: A rental agreement, in simple terms, is a contract between you (tenant) and the owner (landlord). Think of it as the foundation of a peaceful landlord-tenant relationship. Without it, you're basically playing Jenga with your peace of mind.
normalised: A rental agreement, in simple terms, is a contract between you (tenant) and the owner (landlord). Think of it as the foundation of a peaceful landlord-tenant relationship. Without it, you're basically playing Jenga with your peace of mind.

unnormalised: What should it include? Plenty! Start with the basic stuff: your names, the property address, rent amount (Rs. 25,000/month, maybe?), security deposit (usually, 2-3 months' rent). Then, get into the nitty-gritty: who pays for maintenance? What happens if the AC breaks down? What are the move-in/move-out procedures?
normalised: What should it include? Plenty! Start with the basic stuff: your names, the property address, rent amount (rupees twenty five thousand per month, maybe?), security deposit (usually, two to three months' rent). Then, get into the nitty-gritty: who pays for maintenance? What happens if the A C breaks down? What are the move-in slash move-out procedures?

unnormalised: Remember to specify the lock-in period (6 months? 1 year?) and notice period (usually 1 month). This prevents you from suddenly moving out during Onam celebrations and leaving your landlord scrambling.
normalised: Remember to specify the lock-in period (six months? one year?) and notice period (usually one month). This prevents you from suddenly moving out during Onam celebrations and leaving your landlord scrambling.

unnormalised: Pro-tip: Registering your agreement is a good idea, especially in cities like Mumbai. It provides legal backing and can be helpful in case of disputes.
normalised: Pro-tip: Registering your agreement is a good idea, especially in cities like Mumbai. It provides legal backing and can be helpful in case of disputes.

unnormalised: Don't be shy to negotiate terms! This is your chance to tailor the agreement to your specific needs. Always read the document carefully before signing.
normalised: Don't be shy to negotiate terms! This is your chance to tailor the agreement to your specific needs. Always read the document carefully before signing.

unnormalised: Finally, consider getting it reviewed by a lawyer. A small price to pay for avoiding future headaches, right? Happy renting, folks!
normalised: Finally, consider getting it reviewed by a lawyer. A small price to pay for avoiding future headaches, right? Happy renting, folks!
